Award.AwardTitle: Collaborative Research: Adaptive Testing and Rare-Event Analysis of High-Dimensional Data
Award.AbstractNarration:
This project aims at developing adaptively powerful testing procedures for high-dimensional data with applications in genetics, genomics and neuroimaging. Due to recent biotechnological advances, large amounts of high-throughput and high-dimensional molecular and imaging data have been collected, resulting in a number of new and challenging statistical questions. One question is how polygenic testing in genome-wide association studies (GWAS) may be used to answer whether some of the millions of genetic variants are associated with a complex disease like Alzheimer's disease. The answer to this question is important to uncovering disease-related genes, and thus developing effective prevention and treatment strategies. The focus on rigorous hypothesis testing to avoid false discoveries, while maximizing the chance for true discoveries, is critical to modern genetic, genomic and other omic studies. The methods will be applied to data related to Alzheimer's disease, for which currently there is no cure, and more powerful analysis methods are urgently needed to unravel the underlying biology. Graduate students will be involved in the conduct of the research and development of the computational tools, and publicly available software packages will be developed for use by other biomedical researchers.

This research will advance the frontiers of modern statistical methodology in hypothesis testing with high-dimensional data and related rare event assessment. Powerful adaptive methods for testing high-dimensional mean parameters in generalized linear models as well as high-dimensional covariance matrix structures will be developed. The adaptive test statistics are constructed based on high-dimensional high-order von Mises V-statistics and U-statistics, and will provide uniformly high power against sparse, dense, as well as moderately sparse or dense signals for flexible asymptotic regimes. Another thrust of the research deals with the challenging and important rare-event estimation problem in analysis of genome-wide molecular and neuroimaging data, where a high stringent statistical significance level is usually needed. To evaluate such small probabilities, the research will lead to theoretical tail probability approximations as well as efficient Monte Carlo methods using non-standard change-of-measure techniques.

This project contributes to developing adaptively powerful testing procedures for high-dimensional data with applications in genetics, genomics, and neuroimaging. Due to recent biotechnological advances, large amounts of high-throughput and high-dimensional molecular and imaging data have been collected, resulting in a number of new and challenging statistical questions. The answer to this question is important to uncovering disease-related genes, and thus developing effective prevention and treatment strategies. The focus on rigorous hypothesis testing to avoid false discoveries, while maximizing the chance for true discoveries, is critical to modern genetic, genomic, and other omic studies.

This research advances the frontiers of modern statistical methodology in hypothesis testing with high-dimensional data and related rare event assessment. Powerful adaptive methods for testing high-dimensional mean parameters in generalized linear models as well as high-dimensional covariance matrix structures are developed. The adaptive test statistics are constructed based on high-dimensional high-order von Mises V-statistics and U-statistics, and provide uniformly high power against sparse, dense, as well as moderately sparse or dense signals for flexible asymptotic regimes. Another thrust of the research deals with the challenging and important rare-event estimation problem in the analysis of genome-wide molecular and neuroimaging data, where a high stringent statistical significance level is usually needed. To evaluate such small probabilities, the research develops theoretical tail probability approximations as well as efficient Monte Carlo methods using non-standard change-of-measure techniques. The developed methods are also applied to data related to Alzheimer's disease, for which currently there is no cure, and more powerful analysis methods are urgently needed to unravel the underlying biology.

The research results have been disseminated to communities of interest. This project has led to 20 publications in top statistics journals, such as the Annals of Statistics, Journal of the American Statistical Association, Biometrika, Journal of Machine Learning Research, Biometrics, Statistica Sinica, and Psychometrika. There are also 8 manuscripts currently under revision or review in top journals. The PI and his students have presented the research results in several major statistical conferences and seminars. The developed software codes have been distributed to several research groups who have shown interest in the research and requested it, and the codes are also shared publically.

In addition to the research activities, the PI has also been actively involved in mentoring and training students. (1) The PI has been mentoring (or mentored) 7 Ph.D. students. Particularly, the PI has two Ph.D. students who successfully graduated in 2020. One of them, Yuqi Gu, successfully defended her thesis in March 2020 and will join the Statistics Department at Columbia University as a tenure-track Assistant Professor in 2021. The PI’s graduate students have received various awards and recognitions, such as the Rackham Predoctoral Fellowship, Institute of Mathematical Statistics (IMS) Lawrence D. Brown Ph.D. Student Award, IMS Hannan Graduate Student Travel Award, and Joint Statistical Meeting Biometrics Section Travel Award. (2) The PI has supervised four undergraduate students for research activities at the University of Michigan since 2017. Three of them did their Honors Thesis under the PI's supervision. In particular, Ms. Song received the Outstanding Undergraduate Major Award from the Statistics Department in 2019 and presented her research at the undergraduate graduation ceremony. 

The PI has also received awards from professional statistical societies, thanks to the support of this grant on his research activities. Particularly, he received the Outstanding Young Researcher Award (2019) from the International Chinese Statistical Association. He also received the Bernoulli Society New Researcher Award (2019) and delivered an invited talk at the 62nd World Statistics Congress.

The findings and outcomes of this project also contribute to advancement in other disciplines, such as biological and social sciences. In addition to alleviating the associated technical difficulty by presenting the theoretical and methodological developments, this project would also arm practitioners with a computational tool and software packages to explore and expand the use of the proposed methods to other domains of applications and solve real-world problems.
